question: Who is the instructor of this course?
ground_truth: The instructor is Prof. Chengwei QIN from AI Thrust, Information Hub at HKUST(GZ).

question: What is the course code?
ground_truth: The course code is AIAA 3102: Python Programming for Artificial Intelligence.

question: Where is the class location?
ground_truth: The class is held in Room 148, E1.

question: What time is the class?
ground_truth: The class meets on Thursday from 09:00AM to 11:50AM.

question: What is the section number?
ground_truth: The section number is L01 (6368).

question: Who are the teaching assistants?
ground_truth: The TAs are Ziqin Gong (PhD in AI, email: zgong681@connect.hkust-gz.edu.cn) and Yuchen Liu (PhD in DSA, email: yliu356@connect.hkust-gz.edu.cn).

question: What is Prof. Qin's educational background?
answer: Bachelor's degree from THU, PhD degree from NTU
ground_truth: Prof. Qin has a Bachelor's degree from Tsinghua University (THU) and a PhD degree from Nanyang Technological University (NTU).

question: What awards has Prof. Qin received?
answer: EMNLP Outstanding Paper Award 2024 and ACL Area Chair Award 2023
ground_truth: Prof. Qin received the EMNLP Outstanding Paper Award in 2024 (for LLM Reasoning) and the ACL Area Chair Award in 2023 (for Multimodality).

question: What is Prof. Qin's research area?
ground_truth: Prof. Qin works on Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Large Language Models (LLMs).

question: Where has Prof. Qin worked before?
ground_truth: Prof. Qin has experience working at Meta AI and AWS AI.

question: What are the main learning objectives of this course?
answer: Develop core programming concepts, gain Python proficiency, learn ML/DL implementation, and acquire practical AI skills
ground_truth: The course aims to: 1) Develop a solid understanding of core programming concepts, 2) Gain proficiency in coding with Python, 3) Learn to design and implement programs for Machine Learning and Deep Learning, 4) Acquire practical skills in applying common tools and algorithms for AI development.

question: How many parts is the course divided into?
ground_truth: The course is divided into 4 parts: Part 1 - Python Fundamentals, Part 2 - Python for Machine Learning, Part 3 - Python for Deep Learning and LLMs, Part 4 - Final Project Presentation.

question: What topics are covered in Part 1?
ground_truth: Part 1 covers Python Fundamentals including basics, data types, control flow, functions, and OOP.

question: What topics are covered in Part 2?
ground_truth: Part 2 covers Python for Machine Learning including NumPy, Matplotlib, supervised/unsupervised learning, and model evaluation.

question: What topics are covered in Part 3?
answer: Python for Deep Learning and Large Language Models
ground_truth: Part 3 covers Python for Deep Learning and LLMs including PyTorch, neural networks, transformers, and AI agents.

question: What is covered in Week 1?
answer: Introduction, course info, and Python basics
ground_truth: Week 01 (Sep 04) covers: Introduction – course info, Python basics.

question: What is covered in Week 2?
answer: Python Fundamentals I – data types, operators, collections
ground_truth: Week 02 (Sep 11) covers: Python Fundamentals I – data types, operators, collections.

question: What is covered in Week 3?
answer: Python Fundamentals II – dynamic typing, control flow
ground_truth: Week 03 (Sep 18) covers: Python Fundamentals II – dynamic typing, control flow.

question: What is covered in Week 4?
answer: Python Fundamentals III – functions, lambda, arguments, modules
ground_truth: Week 04 (Sep 25) covers: Python Fundamentals III – functions, lambda, arguments, modules.

question: What is covered in Week 5?
answer: Python Fundamentals IV – exceptions, OOP intro, classes, inheritance
ground_truth: Week 05 (Oct 09) covers: Python Fundamentals IV – exceptions, OOP intro, classes, inheritance.

question: What is covered in Week 6?
ground_truth: Week 06 (Oct 16) covers: Scientific Computing – NumPy, Matplotlib, Seaborn.

question: What is covered in Week 7?
answer: Machine Learning I – basics, supervised vs. unsupervised, simple models
ground_truth: Week 07 (Oct 23) covers: Machine Learning I – basics, supervised vs. unsupervised, simple models.

question: What is covered in Week 9?
answer: Intro to PyTorch – tensors, autograd, simple NN
ground_truth: Week 09 (Nov 06) covers: Intro to PyTorch – tensors, autograd, simple neural networks.

question: When is Deep Learning I covered?
ground_truth: Week 10 (Nov 13) covers: Deep Learning I – architectures, optimization, training.

question: When are LLMs and transformers covered?
ground_truth: Week 11 (Nov 20) covers: Deep Learning II – LLMs, transformers, pretraining, fine-tuning.

question: What is covered in Week 12?
answer: Deep Learning III – AI agents, RL overview, agent demo
ground_truth: Week 12 (Nov 27) covers: Deep Learning III – AI agents, RL overview, agent demo.

question: When is the final project presentation?
ground_truth: Week 13 (Dec 04) is for: Final Project – presentations, reflection, wrap-up.

question: When is Week 8 scheduled?
ground_truth: Week 08 is on October 30 and covers: Machine Learning II – evaluation, regularization, ensembles.

question: Is there an exam in this course?
ground_truth: There is no exam in this course. The focus is on progress and improvement.

question: How many free absences are allowed?
ground_truth: Everyone is allowed 2 free absences.

question: Is attendance recorded?
ground_truth: Attendance will be recorded in every class.

question: How many in-class practices count toward the grade?
ground_truth: Each class will include several short practice exercises, but only 1–2 practices per class will count toward your grade.

question: What is the grading distribution?
ground_truth: Final grades are based on 60% concepts and examples + 40% practices.

question: Is there a grading curve?
ground_truth: Final grades will be based on absolute performance; there will be no grading curve.

question: Can students use ChatGPT to write code?
ground_truth: Students should not use Generative AI tools (e.g., ChatGPT) to write their code. This is a fundamental programming course, and the purpose is to develop your own coding skills.

question: What is the policy on plagiarism?
answer: Do not plagiarize. Any copied work will result in serious consequences.
ground_truth: Academic honesty is essential. Do not plagiarize. Any copied work will result in serious consequences.

question: Should students work independently on assignments?
ground_truth: The purpose is for you to develop your own coding skills. Make sure you complete the work independently!

question: How many students can work together on the final project?
ground_truth: Students should work in groups of 1–3 students for the final project.

question: What deliverables are required for the final project?
ground_truth: Final project deliverables include: 1) Write a report that explains your design and findings, 2) Present in class: share your system design, give a demo, and highlight your scientific contributions, 3) Submit your code for evaluation and reproducibility.

question: What should the final project report include?
ground_truth: The report should explain your design and findings.

question: Who created Python?
ground_truth: Python was created by Guido van Rossum in the Netherlands in 1989.

question: When was Python officially released?
ground_truth: Python was officially released in 1991.

question: Where does the name 'Python' come from?
answer: From the British comedy group Monty Python
ground_truth: The name 'Python' was inspired by the British comedy group Monty Python, not the snake.

question: Is Python beginner-friendly?
ground_truth: Python is a beginner-friendly, entry-level programming language that is originally designed for education.

question: What makes Python popular?
answer: It is the most popular programming language
ground_truth: Python is described as the most popular programming language, known for high readability, extensive libraries, and cross-platform compatibility.

question: What are Python's key features for readability?
answer: Meaningful keywords and indentation to define scope
ground_truth: Python has high readability with meaningful keywords and uses indentation to define scope.

question: Does Python support rapid development?
ground_truth: Python supports rapid development and experimentation.

question: How many packages are available on PyPI?
ground_truth: Python has extensive libraries with over 600,000 packages available on PyPI.

question: Is Python cross-platform?
answer: Yes, it works on macOS, Linux, Windows, and Raspberry Pi
ground_truth: Python offers cross-platform compatibility and works on macOS, Linux, Windows, and Raspberry Pi.

question: Does Python have an interactive mode?
ground_truth: Python is a script language with interactive mode for quick testing and debugging.
